1746.Answer:
@AAnoosheh you can use SVM(probabilities=True) which will use Platt's method for calibration of the decision function. Or you can use CallibratedClassifierCV to use Isotonic REgression to calibrate an SVM
you can use Nystrom together with LogisticRegression
just set n_components in Nystroem to n_samples and it will give you exact kernel logistic regression
make_pipe(Nystroem(n_components=n_samples), LogisticRegression())
does kernel logistic regression
platt's method in libsvm does 5-fold cross-validation, so it is 5 times as expensive at one SVM.
I don't even know how one would implement KLR in any efficient way, as the dual is dense
I guess you could do SMO or a similar coordinate descent solver?
anyhow, I would expect SVM+Platt do be much faster than KLR, unless you set the parameters such that all samples are support vectors

4372.Answer:
thats just chaning how you look at it, not really changing the properties of it
just checking I understand your problem though. You are saying in your training set, you have min max output of  something like  .2 - .6 and so you are scaling that to 0-1.
It depends on the problem you are trying to solve. You'll have to decide if it is appropriate for your problem or not.
what min max scaling does in that case is stretch the predictions between .2 and .6 to a higher resolution, and then make evertying outside .2 or .6 equal to each other
if that makes sense to do will be application specific
